newsitem.title: GERMANY: German shares seek refuge after stormy day.
newsitem.headline: German shares seek refuge after stormy day.

text.p: German shares settled into calmer territory late on Tuesday after being buffeted by a see-sawing dollar and uncertain Wall Street on a day which saw prices reach, then lose new record highs.
The IBIS DAX index was down 12.97 points at 3,552.72 points at 1409 GMT, recovering from a session low of 3,337.98 but far from its early high of 3,612.46 points.
Prices had held steady or higher through the day until an initial weak opening on Wall Street and plunge by the dollar sent prices tumbling in a low-volume afternoon session.
Dealers said it was time to sit back and wait.
"It might be time to consolidate. There are a few nerves about on possible interventions in the currency market," said one dealer.
"It was alarming to see the market take such a beating today of all days," he added.
German shares hit several highs earlier in the session, passing the 3,600 IBIS DAX point level for the first time ever and reaching a record DAX close of 3,568.28 points.
But nerves had set in close to Wall Street's opening as dealers expected profits to be taken in the U.S. in the wake of Monday's strong gains.
But dealers said most of the losses in late trade were technically driven and could be quickly reversed.
Losses on index heavyweights like Siemens AG, down 1.27 marks at 97.41 marks, were due to profit-taking, dealers said.

Software group SAP AG was also weak, resuming a decline on Monday after news of a probe into alleged insider dealing in its shares. However dealers also downplayed this development as likely to be short-lived.
Utility Veba AG continued to outperform, up 2.90 marks at 93.10 marks, on well-received first quarter earnings.
